intro: Tapanhuacanga goiasensis, commonly known as the Goiás mountain vine, is a climbing plant native to the Cerrado biome of Brazil. It is characterized by its woody stems and heart-shaped leaves with a velvety texture. The plant produces small, fragrant flowers that are typically white or pale pink, followed by orange-red berries. It thrives in well-drained soils and is adapted to the seasonal climate of its native habitat. Due to its limited distribution, it is considered a rare and ecologically significant species.
